title: 109_hr5612
content: The Act titled "Chattahoochee National Forest Act of 2006" establishes the Mountaintown National Scenic Area within the Chattahoochee National Forest in Georgia. The Mountaintown National Scenic Area is established in the Chattahoochee National Forest in Georgia, covering approximately 13,382 acres. The Secretary of Agriculture will submit a final map and boundary description to Congress, with the map available for public inspection. The Mountaintown National Scenic Area in the Chattahoochee National Forest, Georgia, spans 13,382 acres. The Secretary of Agriculture will provide a final map and boundary description for public inspection. The management of the scenic area aims to protect and preserve its scenic quality, water quality, natural characteristics, and wildlife habitat. The Secretary will develop a management plan for the Mountaintown National Scenic Area within three years, conforming to specified purposes and taking precedence over conflicting laws and regulations. This plan will be an amendment to the Chattahoochee National Forest's land and resource management plan. The management plan for the Chattahoochee National Forest prohibits new road construction within the scenic area, except for access to private lands. Timber harvest is not allowed, except for fire control and public safety. Motorized travel is also not permitted. Motorized travel is not allowed in the scenic area, except for administrative use and wildlife management projects. Wildfires will be suppressed to maintain management purposes. Insect and disease outbreaks may be controlled to preserve scenic quality. Water quality in the area will be maintained or enhanced. Mining activities are subject to valid existing rights. Mining activities in the scenic area are withdrawn from federal lands under mining laws and leasing claims, except for valid existing rights. SEC. 3. DESIGNATION OF ADDITIONAL NATIONAL FOREST SYSTEM LAND AS WILDERNESS IN GEORGIA. Designation of approximately 8,448 acres in Georgia as wilderness areas, including additions to existing Southern Nantahala, Blood Mountain, and Brasstown Wilderness areas. Designation of new wilderness areas in Georgia, including Duck Branch (190 acres), Wilson Cove (563 acres), Ellicott Rock Addition (562 acres), Foster Branch (165 acres), Ken Mountain (527 acres), Helton Creek (2,451 acres), and Tripp Branch (638 acres). Secretary to submit final maps and boundary descriptions to Congress. The Secretary may correct errors in maps and boundary descriptions for designated wilderness areas. Lands shall be administered in accordance with the Wilderness Act. Effective date references in the Wilderness Act apply to the date of enactment of this Act. Fish and wildlife provisions apply as per section 4(d)(7). (3) Fish and wildlife provisions in the Chattahoochee National Forest are not affected by this section. (4) Federal land designated as wilderness is withdrawn from various forms of use, subject to existing rights.
